So then I try

Hi, Julia deals with *Nothing* *type* in such way that an object initialized with *nothing* does/returns nothing, in other words, the *Assignment operator =* can deal with *Nothing type*. That feature and the Nothing type evaluation isnothing() are useful to develop algorithm. In order to fully take advantage of Nothing type could you consider *extended Nothing type to other operators*? For examples:
1/ a = 1 + nothing should return 1
2/ a=nothing
    a[:,:] or view() should do nothing
Am I the one how need that feature?
Best.

messages.text:
This pattern seems wierd to me:
```    retval = false 
    for i = 3:5 
        retval = calc_true_false_value()
        if retval 
            return retval
        end       
    end    
    return retval```
I need that `if` statement there because if `retval = true`  for `i  = 4` (but false for `i = 5`), it overwrites the value for the final return statement. In other words, I want the function to return as soon as `retval = true` for either `i = 3, 4, 5`. I think there is a better way to do this, maybe a while loop?

messages.text:
Question about JLD2: I was surprised by this behavior:
```using JLD2

@save "test.jld2" v = [2,4,6]

global jldfile = jldopen("test.jld2", "r")

function f(perm)
    v = jldfile["v"]
    return permute!(v, perm)
end

f([1,2,3]) # [2,4,6]  <-- expected
f([3,2,1]) # [6,4,2]  <-- expected
f([1,2,3]) # [6,4,2]  <-- surprise: actually changed `jldfile["v"]`.```
It seems that if I open a .jld file (`jldfile` above), I'm not so much holding a reference to data in the jld-file that I can then "request" from, I'm really holding the actual data, so if I request a bit of the data in `jldfile`, I literally get that data - not a copy of it - and if I then modify it, any subsequent request for the same data-field in `jldfile` would give me back a modified version.
Can someone explain why this is working this way? I was kind of caught off guard by this (I guess because I had thought it would be a copy on every new "request").

messages.text:
I have a general question about Julia's multithreading; specifically about defaults. Should it be easier to limit the number of threads used by a Julia program in common cases?
Background: We're developing a code that's intended to be run on a cluster, with many jobs running simultaneously on each node. To make the best use of the resources, it's important that every Julia job uses only a single thread, and that there is one job per CPU core on each node. To achieve this, we tried using the `julia -t1` option, but that's not enough. In our code, it was also necessary to do
```using LinearAlgebra
using FFTW
BLAS.set_num_threads(1)
FFTW.set_num_threads(1)```
It took us a while to figure out that these libraries will default to using multiple threads. I'm wondering if it would make a sense if there were a convention for libraries to "automatically" pick up the `-t1`  option to Julia? The motivation is, obviously, to avoid simultaneous Julia processes from slowing each other down.

I'm attempting to debug some knotty `ccall` calls and in doing so I realise that I don't know how the layout of structs works. I find the following unexpected but perhaps I'm being naive.

```julia> struct Bar
       a::Int8
       b::Int16
       c::Int32
       d::Int64
       e::Int128
       f::Ptr{Nothing}
       g::Ptr{Nothing}
       end

julia> structinfo(T) = [(fieldoffset(T,i), fieldname(T,i), fieldtype(T,i)) for i = 1:fieldcount(T)];

julia> structinfo(Bar)
7-element Vector{Tuple{UInt64, Symbol, DataType}}:
 (0x0000000000000000, :a, Int8)
 (0x0000000000000002, :b, Int16)
 (0x0000000000000004, :c, Int32)
 (0x0000000000000008, :d, Int64)
 (0x0000000000000010, :e, Int128)
 (0x0000000000000020, :f, Ptr{Nothing})

It is not exported from Base, so we cannot count on it always being there -- it is now, and has been there a good while.  The most portable, safest approach would avoid using any function that is not a documented part of Julia's public function/type/etc .

Dear Julia users,
I am using a Finite element package JuAFEM to run some simple FEM elasticity problems. I am facing a problem generating the vtk file. It says 'dh' not defined but in the code, dh is already defined. I am quite new to Julia. Please help. Below is the code

messages.text:
```using JuAFEM
using BlockArrays, SparseArrays, LinearAlgebra

   corners = [Vec{2}((0.0,  0.0)),
              Vec{2}((1.0, 0.0)),
              Vec{2}((1.0, 1.0)),
              Vec{2}((0.0, 1.0))]
   grid = generate_grid(QuadraticQuadrilateral, (1, 1), corners);
   

#Interpolation & Quadrature rule
function create_values(interpolation_u)
   # quadrature rules
   qr     = QuadratureRule{2,RefCube}(3)
   face_qr = QuadratureRule{1,RefCube}(3)

   # geometric interpolation
   interpolation_geom = Lagrange{2,RefCube,2}()

   # cell and facevalues for u
   cellvalues_u = CellVectorValues(qr, interpolation_u, interpolation_geom)
   facevalues_u = FaceVectorValues(face_qr, interpolation_u, interpolation_geom)
   return cellvalues_u, facevalues_u
end;


function create_dofhandler(grid, ipu)
   dh = DofHandler(grid)
   push!(dh, :u, 2, ipu) # displacement
   close!(dh)
   return dh
end;

function create_bc(dh)
   dbc = ConstraintHandler(dh)

   add!(dbc, Dirichlet(:u, getfaceset(dh.grid, "bottom"), (x,t) -> 0.0, [2]))
   add!(dbc, Dirichlet(:u, getfaceset(dh.grid, "left") , (x,t) -> 0.0, [1]))
   close!(dbc)
   t = 0.0
   update!(dbc, t)
   return dbc
end;

function create_stiffness(::Val{dim}) where {dim}
   E = 1.0
   ν = 0.3
   λ = E*ν / ((1+ν) * (1 - 2ν))
   μ = E / (2(1+ν))
   δ(i,j) = i == j ? 1.0 : 0.0
   g(i,j,k,l) = λ*δ(i,j)*δ(k,l) + μ*(δ(i,k)*δ(j,l) + δ(i,l)*δ(j,k))
   C = SymmetricTensor{4, dim}(g);
   return C
end;

function doassemble(cellvalues_u::CellVectorValues{dim},
                   facevalues_u::FaceVectorValues{dim}, K::SparseMatrixCSC, grid::Grid,
                   dh::DofHandler) where {dim}

   f = zeros(ndofs(dh))
   assembler = start_assemble(K, f)
   nu = getnbasefunctions(cellvalues_u)

   fe = PseudoBlockArray(zeros(nu), [nu]) # local force vector
   ke = PseudoBlockArray(zeros(nu , nu), [nu], [nu]) # local stiffness matrix

   # traction vector
   t = Vec{2}((1.0, 0.0))
   # cache ɛdev outside the element routine to avoid some unnecessary allocations

   for cell in CellIterator(dh)
       fill!(ke, 0)
       fill!(fe, 0)
       assemble_up!(ke, fe, cell, cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, grid, t)
       assemble!(assembler, celldofs(cell), fe, ke)
   end

   return K, f
end;

function assemble_up!(Ke, fe, cell, cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, grid, t)

   n_basefuncs_u = getnbasefunctions(cellvalues_u)
   reinit!(cellvalues_u, cell)
   C = create_stiffness(Val(2))

    @inbounds for q_point in 1:getnquadpoints(cellvalues_u) # loop over quadrature points
       dΩ = getdetJdV(cellvalues_u, q_point)
       for i in 1:n_basefuncs_u # loop over number of ansatz functions
           BuT = symmetric(shape_gradient(cellvalues_u, q_point, i))
           for j in 1:i 
               Bu = symmetric(shape_gradient(cellvalues_u, q_point, j))
               Ke[i, j] += BuT ⊡ C ⊡ Bu * dΩ 
           end
       end
   end
symmetrize_lower!(Ke)

   
   @inbounds for face in 1:nfaces(cell)
       if onboundary(cell, face) && (cellid(cell), face) ∈ getfaceset(grid, "right")
           reinit!(facevalues_u, cell, face)
           for q_point in 1:getnquadpoints(facevalues_u)
               dΓ = getdetJdV(facevalues_u, q_point)
               for i in 1:n_basefuncs_u
                   δu = shape_value(facevalues_u, q_point, i)
                   fe[i] += (δu ⋅ t) * dΓ
               end
           end
       end
   end
end

function symmetrize_lower!(K)
   for i in 1:size(K,1)
       for j in i+1:size(K,1)
           K[i,j] = K[j,i]
       end
   end
end;



function solve(interpolation_u)

   # grid, dofhandler, boundary condition
   
   dh = create_dofhandler(grid, interpolation_u)
   dbc = create_bc(dh)

   # cellvalues
   cellvalues_u, facevalues_u = create_values(interpolation_u)

   # assembly and solve
   K = create_sparsity_pattern(dh);
   K, f = doassemble(cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, K, grid, dh);
   apply!(K, f, dbc)
   u = Symmetric(K) \ f;
end


quadratic = Lagrange{2,RefCube,2}()
u = solve(quadratic)

println(typeof(u))
println(u)
vtk_grid("sample grid", dh) do vtk
   vtk_point_data(vtk,dh , u)
end```

Hey folks, is there a way to specify fields when defining the default constructor on a struct. I have a relatively long struct for my default settings (like 15 fields).

```struct MyStruct
   field1::Int64
   field2::Float64
   field3::Float64
end

MyStruct() = do
   field1 = 5
   field2 = 2.0
   field3 = 4.0
end ```
I think right now I just have to put everything in order in the constructor, like `MyStruct() = MyStruct(5, 2.0, 4.0)`, but that can easily create problems if there are a lot of settings. Just figured I would ask if there is an easier way. I could used a namedtuple, but started with using structs, so wanted to be consistent. But it is probably a good thing to know if something like this is possible.

Is this expected `hash`ing behaviour?
```julia> a = [rand(0:1, 200) for i in 1:10000]
julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
true```
It seems to be different with smaller vectors:
```julia> a = [rand(0:1, 200) for i in 1:10]
julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
false```

I can't seem to get this right: so I ask here : ) I want to create a block-matrix type that can hold 4 blocks to form a 2x2 block matrix. Something along the lines of
```struct BlockMatrix{T, T11 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T12 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T21 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T22 <: AbstractMatrix{T}} <: AbstractMatrix{T}
  A11::T11
  A12::T12
  A21::T21
  A22::T22
end```
The idea is that it can hold all kinds of matrices for each block, depending on what is chosen during construction, be it sparse arrays, low-rank matrix or dense matrix. As there is a lot of possible combinations here I am not sure whether this is the right approach to play nice with type inference. Shou;ld I perhaps cut out the `T11, T12...`  types and instead use `A11::Union{Matrix{T}, LowRankMatrix{T}}`  etc.? Thanks in advance for your inputs :slightly_smiling_face:
